entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud: Smarter Currency Conversion with Just Ask
entry.content:
When it comes to making data-driven decisions, numbers alone don‚Äôt always tell the full story, especially when you‚Äôre operating across markets, regions, or currencies. That‚Äôs why SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) makes it easy to bring currency intelligence into your conversations with just ask, our natural language-powered analytics feature. 

Whether you're analyzing revenue in local currencies or tracking global sales performance in EUR or USD, Just Ask helps you get the answers instantly and accurately. No complex scripting or data wrangling is required, just natural questions and smart insights 

Flexible Currency Options, Built for Real-World Business Needs 

Different teams have different reporting requirements; some need dynamic currency switching, while others rely on predefined conversions or local currencies by region. With SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere (DSP), you have a range of options to choose from depending on how your data is modeled. 

Below is a quick overview of the supported scenarios. After the table, we‚Äôll walk you through each one with real-world context and guidance. 

How Just Ask Supports Currency Conversion with SAP Analytics Cloud Models vs. SAP Datasphere Models:

 

 

Conversion Category 

Conversion Type 

Just Ask on SAC Models 

Just Ask on DSP Models 

1 

Based on story-level calculation in SAC 

SAC story-level calculation based on model‚Äôs currency conversion  

‚úÖSupported for basic (non-calculated) measures 

üóìÔ∏è Planned 

2 

Fixed-Measure Conversion as specified in model 

Predefined measures with hardcoded currency conversion applied at model level (e.g., Sales_EUR) 

‚úÖSupported 

‚úÖ Supported 

3 

Currency Dimension 

Target currency (currency concept on model-level) determined dynamically via a linked dimension (e.g., region or entity). Currency varies based on dimension member values. 

‚úÖSupported 
üîÑ Just Ask auto-adds currency dimension for breakdown 

‚ö†Ô∏èSupported, but Just Ask does not auto-add the currency dimension 

4 

Currency as Model Variable 
(set by end user) 

Currency set via model variable; applies at query execution. Can be modified post-query in Just Ask. 

‚úÖ Supported 

üîß Variable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

‚úÖSupported 

üîßVariable can be updated interactively in Just Ask 

5 

Currency as Model Variable 
(included in end user‚Äôs query) 

Currency model as variable. End user is asking for it in natural language query (e.g., Sales in CAD).  

‚úÖ Supported 

 ‚ùå Not supported 

 

Now, let‚Äôs explore each type in more detail: 

1. Story-level Calculation for Currency Conversion 

Best for: Fast ad hoc queries where users want to convert currencies without pre-built measures. 

With just ask, you can instantly convert currency values at runtime using the model‚Äôs built-in conversion logic. Simply ask a question like: 

‚ÄúWhat were our 2024 sales in EUR?‚Äù 

Just ask pulls the latest conversion rates from the model‚Äôs currency table and returns values in your specified currency without any manual setup. 

Available for SAP Analytics Cloud Universal Models where currency conversion is enabled in the modeler. 

Requirements: 

  • The measure must be non-calculated 
  • The unit type must be defined as "currency" 

Behind the scenes: The booking date is used as the conversion reference, and if you paste the just ask result into your story, the converted measure is automatically created and saved.

Currently not supported for SAP Datasphere models, but support is planned in the future. 

 

2. Fixed Currency Measures 

Best for: Use cases where your model already contains hardcoded currency values. 

If your data model includes measures like Sales_EUR or Revenue_USD, you can easily query those in just ask with no extra steps needed. 

Fully supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere. 

These measures are typically created at the model level during data preparation and remain consistent across dashboards and stories. 

Think of this as a one-time setup option: once fixed currency measures are defined in your model, just ask treats each one like a standard metric with no extra configuration needed. 

 

3. Currency by Dimension 

Best for: Companies that operate across multiple regions and need to report in local currencies. 

Some organizations need to show currency values that align with specific regions or entities. With dimension-based currency measures, the appropriate currency is retrieved dynamically based on a linked dimension like country, business unit, or region. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud models, this is fully supported, and just ask automatically inserts the corresponding currency dimension to the result, making it easy to interpret values without mixing currencies in totals. 

In SAP Datasphere models, this functionality is supported, but just ask won‚Äôt auto-add the currency dimension. That means users must manually add the dimension via the Post Search builder panel or specify it in the query. 

Use this approach when reporting across multiple business units or local subsidiaries; your stakeholders will appreciate seeing values in their native currencies. 

 

4. Model Variable Currency 

Best for: Dashboards and queries where users need flexibility to switch currencies based on preference. 

Model variables offer dynamic control over currency selection. For example, users can switch between USD and EUR using a dropdown or prompt, without changing the structure of the query. 

Supported in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere 

Just ask allows users to update the variable interactively through the data card, or it can be preset by default in Joule for seamless integration into more advanced workflows. 

 

5. Specifying Currency Variable in the Question 

Best for: Quick, natural language queries using variable-driven currency measure. 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, you can query a variable-driven currency measure and specify the target currency directly in your query. for example: 

‚ÄúShow me SalesVar in CAD.‚Äù 

Just ask automatically parses the request, updates the target currency variable, and shows results accordingly. 

Supported only for SAP Analytics Cloud models. 

 

Built for Flexibility. Ready for Scale. 

Whether you‚Äôre a financial analyst tracking global revenue, a sales leader monitoring regional performance, or an operations manager comparing results across subsidiaries, currency conversion is essential to making confident, context-aware decisions. 

With just ask in SAP Analytics Cloud, you get a system that adapts to your business needs: 

  • Conversational queries that feel intuitive 
  • Multiple currency handling methods, from fixed to dynamic 
  • Smart defaults that prevent common errors like mixed currency aggregation 

 

Looking to do more? 

Just ask is even more powerful when paired with Analytical Insights in Joule, allowing you to bring AI-driven insights into your everyday workflow without leaving the tools you already use. 

Need help modeling currency for just ask in your SAP Analytics Cloud or SAP Datasphere environment? 
Check out our help documentation.

entry.title: EL31 device state not properly retrieved
entry.content:
Hello,

In EL31 transaction, when a MR document is selected, the device state (i.e. value 5) is taken from the selected register (without time slice?). Then, if another MRO of other register for the same date is selected, the device state is the same as the previous register.

In case that you select the MROs in the diferent sequence as before, that is, first the second register (i.e. value 6 for device state) and then the first register, the device state for this first register will be 6. So the sequence how the MR documents are selected influence in the data because it is not refreshing properly

Our custom validations depends on the device state, so those validations overview provide different results depending on the sequence of the selection of the MR document.

Also, it is very weird that the device state can be different for 2 registers at the same date

Do you have any idea about this behavior?

Many thanks in advance,

Antonio

entry.title: X-Ray Your Pricing Logic: A Deep Dive with the Analyze Pricing Documents App
entry.content:
Introduction

Imagine you've meticulously designed a complex pricing scheme in SAP Subscription Billing, complete with multiple lookups, formulas, and advanced logic. How can you be certain it behaves exactly as intended under various conditions before it goes live? How do you test a specific scenario without the overhead of creating test subscriptions and running full bill cycles?

The Analyze Pricing Documents app solves this exact challenge. It acts as a dedicated simulator for your pricing models, giving you a detailed, x-ray view into the execution of your pricing logic in complete isolation.

In this post, we'll walk through a practical example using the "X-Ray as a Service" model. This scenario is used in the official SAP Subscription Billing Pricing Configuration Guide and was also featured in our popular blog post on cross-billing cycle aggregation. We'll use it to demonstrate how to leverage this powerful tool for your own pricing validation.

 

Step-by-Step: Analyzing "X-Ray as a Service"

1. Understanding the Scenario and the Example Data 

Our "X-Ray as a Service" model uses a straightforward but powerful pricing structure: a monthly recurring fee plus tiered usage charges for the number of X-ray images consumed.

To test this, we'll simulate a price calculation using the same data that drives a live rating. For our simulation, we'll provide a set of attributes that describe the charges to be rated. These are split between header data, which applies to the whole document, and item data, which is specific to each charge.

2. Creating the Analysis Document

First, launch the Analyze Pricing Documents app and click Create. This opens the new document in edit mode.
On the Header tab, define a unique code for your document and enter a description. This helps you identify the purpose of this specific test case later.
Next, switch to the Document tab. This is where you'll build the test scenario. Select the pricing scheme that you want to test from the dropdown list. It's also strongly recommended to set the priced document currency. In our example, this is USD.

Once these basic settings are defined, you can proceed to add the attributes that drive the pricing logic.

3. Populating Header Data

To maintain attributes at the header level, the workflow is straightforward:

  1. In the document tree on the left, select the Attributes node directly under the Document root node.
  2. The details area on the right now shows the configuration for header attributes. Click the Add button to choose fields.
  3. Select the attributes you need (for example, marketId and customerId) and click Add Attributes to add them to the tree.
  4. Enter the values for these attributes directly in the tree on the left.

For our example, add and populate these attributes:

  • marketId: "A1"
  • customerId: "123456789"
    (example value)
 

Why are these header attributes? We define them at the header level because they are constant for the entire rating. Every line item in this simulation will be priced for this customer and market.

4. Configuring the First Billing Cycle

Now, we'll configure the line items to represent the charges for the first month, March 2025. A new document is automatically created with one initial item in the tree, so we'll start by configuring it. Each item needs a pricingDate. This date is critical as it determines which price version is used. How this date is derived in a live scenario is described in the SAP Help Portal.

  • Item 1: The Recurring Fee. We'll configure the first item to represent the recurring fee. The process for adding attributes to an item is the same as for the header: Select the item's Attributes node in the tree and use the details area on the right to add the required fields. Add and populate the following attributes. Note that rateSubElement and bundleProductCode can be left empty for this scenario.

  • productCode: "X-RAY"
  • bundleProductCode: ""
  • ratingType: "recurring"
  • rateElement: "USERS"
  • rateSubElement: ""
  • quantity: "50" "EA"
  • prorata: "1/1"
  • periodicity: "calendar-monthly"
  • subscriptionStart: "2025-03-01"
  • billingCycleStart: "2025-03-01"
  • billingCycleEnd: "2025-03-31"
  • ratingPeriodStart: "2025-03-01"
  • ratingPeriodEnd: "2025-03-31"
 

  • Item 2: The Usage Charge. For efficiency, copy the first item. Then, modify only the attributes that differ for the usage charge. Note that cumulativeQuantity is a usage-specific attribute and needs to be added for item 2.

    • ratingType: "usage"
    • rateElement: "IMAGES"
    • quantity: "600" "EA"
    • cumulativeQuantity: "600" "EA"

Why are quantity and cumulativeQuantity the same here? In the first billing period, the consumption within the period (quantity) is identical to the total consumption to date (cumulativeQuantity). This will change in the next step.

5. Adding Items for a Second Billing Cycle

Typically, one billing cycle is rated at a time. However, a backdated subscription change or other scenarios can cause multiple cycles to be rated at once, a scenario the app makes easy to simulate.

  • Duplicate the two line items you just created so that you have a total of four items.
  • For the two new items (items 3 and 4), update all date-related attributes to reflect the next month, April 2025.
  • On the new usage item (item 4), set the quantity to "500 EA" for April's consumption.
  • Crucially, update its cumulativeQuantity to "1100". This sum of the previous cycle's quantity (600 EA) and the current cycle's quantity (500 EA) is essential for the correct tier calculation.

6. Testing Overridable Fields (Optional)

You can also simulate field overrides, a powerful feature for testing negotiated prices or other special conditions. For this, you use both panels of the UI:

  1. In the document tree on the left, expand an item and its Price Elements node.
  2. Select the specific price element you want to override (for example, Discount).
  3. The panel on the right updates to show the details for this price element. Go to its Configuration tab.
  4. Click the Add Overridable Fields link. A list of all fields defined as overridable in the price element specification appears.
  5. Select the field you want to test and add it.
  6. The new overridable field now appears in the document tree under the price element, where you can enter a value for your simulation.

This allows you to test scenarios like a negotiated discount without needing to create an actual subscription with customized discount.

 

Verification: Interpreting the Results

After clicking Analyze, the app populates the document tree on the left with the calculated results. You can now interpret the outcome of your simulation by drilling down into the details.

  • High-Level Results in the Tree: The first thing you'll notice is that the tree now displays the calculated amounts. Each Item line shows its total net value, and each Price Element under it shows its specific monetary amount. A value of "-" indicates that a price element was evaluated but its conditions were not met for that charge. This gives you an immediate overview of the entire calculation.

  • Detailed Breakdown of a Price Element: To understand how a specific amount was calculated, select a price element in the tree (for example, UsagePrice). The details area on the right updates, showing the Result tab. Here you can find a comprehensive summary, including the base quantity used for the calculation and, for tiered pricing, a Price Element Parts table that shows exactly how consumption was split across the different tiers.

  • Step-by-Step Execution with Pricing Traces: For the ultimate level of detail, look at the Pricing Traces table at the bottom of the Result tab. This provides a step-by-step log of the pricing logic's execution path. To see the precise data used in any step, click the details icon (magnifier) in that row. A popover appears, showing the exact inputs (like quantity and field values) and the configuration (like the full tier scale) that were used in that specific calculation step.

Why is this trace so valuable? This is the core of the app's power. It removes all guesswork. You can prove not only what the result is, but why it is correct by following the exact logic path and seeing the data used at every step of the calculation.

 

A Bridge to Operations: Debugging from the Monitor Rating App

The Analyze Pricing Documents app is not just for proactive testing; it's also a powerful reactive debugging tool.

  • Scenario: Imagine rating fails due to unexpected or incorrect subscription data.
  • Starting Point: The Monitor Rating app provides a direct navigation link to analyze these failures.
  • Workflow: In the Monitor Rating app, find a rating error and click the Analyze Pricing button. You're taken directly to the Analyze Pricing Documents app, with a new analysis document pre-populated with the exact data from the failed rating.
  • Value: This seamless integration makes root cause analysis incredibly fast. There is no need to manually reproduce the error; the system does it for you, allowing you to immediately see what went wrong in the pricing logic.

 

Conclusion & Summary

The Analyze Pricing Documents app is an essential tool for anyone building or managing pricing models in SAP Subscription Billing. It empowers you to both proactively test your logic and reactively debug production issues with unmatched precision.

By decoupling pricing simulation from the full subscription and billing life cycle, you gain speed, agility, and a higher degree of quality assurance. It's the ultimate tool for ensuring your complex pricing schemes are correct before your first customer is billed.

Please share your thoughts, questions, or experiences with the app in the comments below.

 

Further Reading

  • Blog Post: Configure Cross-Billing Cycle Aggregation for Tier-Based Pricing
  • SAP Help Portal: Analyze Pricing Documents
  • SAP Help Portal: Pricing Configuration Guide

entry.title: Personalized Recommendations in SAP SuccessFactors Opportunity Marketplace: Logic and Data Sources
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs digital world, consumers have come to expect highly personalized experiences, whether it‚Äôs curated content on streaming platforms or product recommendations on online portals. Applying that same level of personalization to career development and progression is no longer a future aspiration; it‚Äôs a reality. SAP SuccessFactors Opportunity Marketplace (OMP) and Career & Talent Development (CTD) are harnessing the power of intelligent AI recommendations to provide employees with meaningful, data-driven guidance aligned to their roles, skills, and aspirations.

Recently, I have had several conversations with customers who are actively using OMP and CTD. A common concern? Their users aren‚Äôt always seeing the ‚Äúright‚Äù personalized recommendations. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk through the recommendation logic and underlying data sources that power these AI-driven suggestions, so you can verify that your configurations and data are set up correctly to deliver the experience your users expect.

While much of this information is available in SAP Help documentation or KBAs, I have compiled it in a simplified table format to make it easier to reference.

So what‚Äôs the magic behind it?

There are two main types of recommendations within SuccessFactors:

  1. Intelligent (AI) Recommendations

  2. Rule-based Recommendations

Think of it like this:

  • Rule-based recommendations are like ‚Äúbecause HR said so.‚Äù

  • AI recommendations are more like ‚Äúbased on your skills, and aspirations‚Ä¶ this might just be your path.‚Äù

In this blog, we will talk about personalized recommendations in OMP and CTD. Let‚Äôs dig into the AI side, because that‚Äôs where things get fun and smart .

Opportunities Type in OMP and Recommendation Logic

There are 5 types of Opportunities and  2 recommendation logics in opportunity marketplace: Intelligent (AI) Recommendations and Rule-based recommendations.

Type

Recommendation Logic

Assignments

Both AI recommendation & Rule-based recommendations

Discover Open Jobs

Both AI recommendation & Rule-based recommendations

Connect with People

Rule based recommendations

Explore Career Options

AI recommendations (Career Explorer) & Rule-based recommendations (Suggested Roles)

Learnings

AI recommendation and Peer/Admin recommendations

Intelligent (AI) recommendations in Opportunity Marketplace

In SAP SuccessFactors Opportunity Marketplace (OMP), the "Top Picks for You" "Ignite Your Role" and ‚ÄòReach your Aspirations‚Äô sections are powered by intelligent recommendations, leveraging SAP AI Business Services. It‚Äôs also called AI Recommendation.

Note: You will see these three sections in OMP, only if Intelligent Recommendations are enabled in your instance. Learn how to enable AI-based recommendations - Enabling Intelligent Recommendations in Opportunity Marketplace | SAP Help Portal

SAP AI Business Services analyzes data from various sources (as outlined below) to identify patterns and generate personalized recommendations :

Key data sources for Intelligent Recommendation -

  • Opportunity Marketplace assignments
  • SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting
  • SAP SuccessFactors Learning

The Machine learning technology recommends opportunities based on user‚Äôs profile and activity data. The intelligent recommendations for each user is also enhanced based on their growth portfolio skills and attributes. The opportunities are more weighted, when their skills/attributes are marked as passionate or been tagged as critical.

  • Top Picks for you displays general recommendations for opportunities based on the employee's overall profile and preferences.
  • Ignite Your Role focuses on opportunities that are relevant to the employee's current job role, helping them develop skills and experiences directly tied to their current job role.
  • Reach Your Aspirations focuses on the user‚Äôs aspirations, including skills/attributes that the user is interested in, or required for the user‚Äôs target role/development goals

1. Recommendation Logic and Data Sources

Section

Opportunity Type

Recommendation Logic

Opportunity Source

Data Source

Visibility & Configuration

Sorting Logic

Top Picks for You

‚Ä¢Assignments

‚Ä¢Open Jobs

‚Ä¢Learning Items

ML-based recommendations based on user profile and activity data. Boosted by user preferences (skills an attributes data marked as passionate and critical).

Max number of recommendations: 100

SAP AI Business Services

‚Ä¢User Profile Data

‚Ä¢User Growth Portfolio data

‚Ä¢Assignment Data

‚Ä¢SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting data

‚Ä¢User Activity data

‚Ä¢Learning data

Requires enabling all content sources (Assignments, Learning, Recruiting, Mentoring). Configure via Manage Opportunity Marketplace + Manage Intelligent Recommendations.

Sorted by internal score > group across types > alignment to skills > priority: Assignment > Job > Mentor > Program

More Info

Ignite Your Role

‚Ä¢Assignments

‚Ä¢Open Jobs

‚Ä¢Learning Items

Focuses on improving current role skills. Following attributes to filter to boost the intelligent recommendations:

‚Ä¢Skills/attributes that the user already have

‚Ä¢Skills/attributes that are needed for the user's current job role

Max number of recommendations: 100

SAP AI Business Services

‚Ä¢User Profile Data

‚Ä¢User Growth Portfolio data

‚Ä¢Assignment Data

‚Ä¢SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting data

‚Ä¢User Activity data

‚Ä¢Learning data

Feature toggled in Admin Center. Requires Growth Portfolio and EC for job hierarchy filtering.

Similar to Top Picks sorting logic.

Reach Your Aspirations

‚Ä¢Assignments

‚Ä¢Open Jobs

‚Ä¢Learning Items

Focuses on aspirational skills and goals.

‚Ä¢Skills/attributes that the user is interested in

‚Ä¢Skills/attributes that are required for the user's target role

‚Ä¢Skills/attributes that are required for the user's develop goals

Max number of recommendations: 100

SAP AI Business Services

‚Ä¢User Profile Data

‚Ä¢User Growth Portfolio data

‚Ä¢Assignment data

‚Ä¢SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting data

‚Ä¢User Activity data

‚Ä¢Learning data

Requires Career Worksheet or Career Explorer enabled. Job role tagging must be in place.

Same as above.

2. Data Sources and Key Data Points Used in ML

Let's say you have enabled Intelligent Recommendations in OMP, but the user is not receiving the right match or recommendations. Make sure the user has the following data points populated. 

Intelligent Recommendations get derived from

 By Using data points‚Ä¶

User Profile Data

‚Ä¢Job Location

‚Ä¢Job Code

‚Ä¢Departments

‚Ä¢Division

 User Growth Portfolio Data

‚Ä¢      Attributes ID

‚Ä¢      Attributes that users are interested in

‚Ä¢      Attributes with the critical tag

Assignment Data

‚Ä¢Assignment Type

‚Ä¢Attributes ID

SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting Data

‚Ä¢Job Title

‚Ä¢Job Location

‚Ä¢Job Posting related Growth Portfolio Attributes

‚Ä¢Applied Jobs

User Activity Data

‚Ä¢Bookmarks of Assignment and Learning Opportunities

‚Ä¢Opportunity Applications

Learning Data

‚Ä¢Learning history data of all employees (and not just those that have the permission to  access recommendations)

‚Ä¢Completions for optional courses (not a required learning item)

‚Ä¢Learning Plan

‚Ä¢Bookmarks

Now, let's explore the recommendation logic in OMP for other Opportunity Types.

Other Opportunities Types and Recommendation Logic in Opportunity Marketplace

Here are the other opportunity types and the corresponding recommendation logic -

Final Thoughts -

That's all! I know it's a lot of tables, but I wasn't sure how else to present this content :). I am not saying SAP SuccessFactors can predict your next career move, but it can provide you with the right recommendations! With AI recommendations, it might come close. Whether you are an implementation partner helping customers implement this or leading your internal rollout, knowing how the engine runs helps you steer the car, not just ride along.

If you‚Äôre a customer exploring what‚Äôs next, or a partner guiding them, now you can peek behind the curtain and say, ‚ÄúAh, that‚Äôs why it recommended a mentor or job role or assignment!

entry.title: Automate PFCG process

entry.title: Re: How to integrate SAP GRDC with Datasphere for public...
entry.content:
Hello @897654208074 

Absolutely, Ahmed, here‚Äôs the precise Public Cloud-only setup with the scope items, the exact communication scenario, and what to type in each field. I‚Äôve cross-checked the IDs and documents.

Here‚Äôs the streamlined, do-this-now version for GRDC ‚Üí Datasphere via OData in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Solution (step-by-step)

Activate scopes in S/4HANA Cloud

  • 1SG Group Reporting ‚Äì Financial Consolidation
  • 287 Group Reporting ‚Äì Data from Group Reporting Data Collection

Create communication artefacts in S/4HANA Cloud

  • Communication User: DSP_GRDC_USER (authentication: user/password)
  • Communication System: DATASPHERE_CONN
    • Inbound Users: add DSP_GRDC_USER
    • Host Name: any descriptive value (not used for auth)
  • Communication Arrangement: SAP_COM_0241 (Finance: Cloud Consolidation Data Collection Integration)
    • System: DATASPHERE_CONN
    • Confirm Inbound shows DSP_GRDC_USER
    • Copy the ‚ÄúAPI-URL‚Äù shown (you‚Äôll need its host for Datasphere)

Create the connection in SAP Datasphere

  • Type: SAP S/4HANA Cloud (OData)
  • Application Server: the host from the Arrangement‚Äôs API-URL (e.g., my123456-api.s4hana.ondemand.com)
  • Port: 443 | Protocol: HTTPS | Authentication: Basic
  • User / Password: DSP_GRDC_USER and its password
  • Test Connection ‚Üí Create

Import the OData services in Datasphere

  • From the connection, browse and import as Remote Tables:
    • API_GRTRANSACTIONDATA_SRV (Group Reporting transaction data ‚Äì read)
    • API_GRMASTERDATA_SRV (Group Reporting master data ‚Äì read)

Quick checks

  • Open <API-URL>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_GRTRANSACTIONDATA_SRV/$metadata in a browser or REST client with Basic auth to verify access.
  • In Datasphere, preview the remote tables, then model views for reporting.

No additional setup is required in Datasphere beyond the connection and imports.

Below are some useful SAP Documentations

Master Data for Group Reporting ‚Äì Read

Group reporting with S/4 HANA Cloud

SAP Best Practices for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Automatic Quota Payout on Termination
entry.content:
We are a Canadian public sector company, and in Time Evaluation we have automated the Quota Payout on Termination process.

Currently, when an employee terminates while on an inactive LOA, Time Evaluation generates a specific set of wage types on the last active day, which payroll successfully pays out if the termination occurs during the inactive LOA. Functionally, everything works fine‚Äîthe system generates the payout hours and payroll processes the payment correctly.

Previously, we used IT0416, which updated IT2006 after termination, ensuring the hours were deducted once payroll paid them. However, with the new automation, the issue we are facing is that IT2006 is not being updated. After termination, the employee‚Äôs quota balance still shows hours remaining in IT2006. This creates problems in two cases:

  • When the employee is rehired, or

  • When payroll runs through IT0003.

Currently, we are handling this manually using IT2013 corrections, but we are looking for a solution where the system automatically updates the IT2006 deduction fields once payroll has paid out the quota hours.

Do you guys have any suggestions or best practices to resolve this issue so that IT2006 is updated automatically in line with the payout?

Thanks

entry.title: ‚ÄúBusiness Excellence with SAP‚Äôs New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How‚Äù
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes ‚Äì Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration ‚Äì Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility ‚Äì Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data ‚Äì Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations ‚Äì Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the ‚ÄúExtensibility‚Äù guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via ‚ÄúSide-by-side‚Äù extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through ‚ÄúS/4 HANA On-stack‚Äù extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple ‚Äúclean vs. not clean‚Äù classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. It‚Äôs about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesn‚Äôt come at the cost of technical debt.

Here‚Äôs what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices ‚Äì Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions ‚Äì Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Build‚Äîall supported by Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure ‚Äì Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API is‚Äîbecause most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A ‚Äì The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released API‚Äôs and extension points.

Level B ‚ÄìExtensions that follow SAP‚Äôs best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C ‚Äì Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP‚Äôs formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D ‚Äì Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don‚Äôt follow SAP‚Äôs guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The ‚ÄúSAP Business Accelerator Hub‚Äù and ‚ÄúCloudification Repository (API Viewer)‚Äù are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C ‚Äì default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP‚Äôs central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in ‚ÄúOn-stack extensibility‚Äù.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public‚Äù and ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Private Edition‚Äù for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn‚Äôt include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API‚Äôs)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of ‚ÄúS/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition‚Äù.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API‚Äôs at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API‚Äôs directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for ‚ÄúSAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn‚Äôt include Classic APIs)
2. Click ‚ÄúShow Filter Bar‚Äù

3. Choose ‚ÄúReleased‚Äù under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on ‚ÄúObject type‚Äù, ‚ÄúSoftware Component‚Äù and ‚ÄúApplication Component‚Äù

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for ‚Äúpurchase_order‚Äù)

4.2 Extension Level B ‚Äì Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP‚Äôs best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API‚Äôs:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Provide Edition (Classic API‚Äôs)
  2. Click ‚ÄúShow Filter Bar‚Äù

3. Choose ‚ÄúClassic API‚Äù in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for ‚Äúsales‚Äù)

4.3 Extension Level C ‚Äì Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP‚Äôs formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither ‚ÄúReleased APIs,‚Äù ‚ÄúClassical APIs,‚Äù nor ‚ÄúAPIs‚Äù at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level C ‚Äì Conditionally Clean

Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that doesn‚Äôt follow SAP‚Äôs guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are ‚ÄúNot APIs‚Äù classified as ‚ÄúNo APIs‚Äù

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Provide Edition (Classic API‚Äôs)
  2. Click ‚ÄúShow Filter Bar

3. Choose ‚ÄúNo API‚Äù in State

4. Results with ‚ÄúNo API‚Äù are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt‚Äîwhile still getting the flexibility they need today.

6. References:

No

entry.title: Changing materials without losing history
entry.content:
I am trying to figure out the best way to handle this situation. My company is a recycling company. Using a process order, we take widgets, disassemble them and separate them into different parts, each different part being a unique Semi Finished Good. Once they are separated, the parts are tested for their quality and then moved into a graded Finished Good material. What is the best way to handle the process for grading?

We are considering doing a material to material transfer to take the SFG to the Graded FG. But the problem with that is that we lose the batch number, the inspection results and traceability to the original widgets. We are also looking into using a rework process order, but that would be a lot more work for the quality team to manage. But in this case, we could copy the inspection results to the new inspection lot (Inspection Results are important for the Certificate of Analysis).

Does anyone have any recommendations on the best way? Is there another way I haven‚Äôt considered?

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: All you need to know about SAP Cloud Availability
entry.content:
Being aware of your cloud system status and upcoming events taking place is a requirement to current businesses setup. SAP ensures that you have a seamless visibility about your cloud solutions by launching the SAP Cloud Availability application. 

 
But you might wonder, how can I access this feature? Well, let me guide you through this process. 

 
SAP Cloud Availability in SAP for Me 

The SAP Cloud Availability application is part of SAP for Me, which is currently the main entry point for support at SAP.  
 
To access the portal, you will need an S-user ID, an identifier issued under SAP‚Äôs customer and partner accounts to allow access to our main support platforms, such as SAP for Me.  
 
If you're unfamiliar with S-users, we recommend checking out this detailed blog post: Learn how to get an S-user ID.  
 

Now, let‚Äôs see how you can find the SAP Cloud Availability:  

  1. Log in to me.sap.com with your S-user ID and password. 
  2. From your homepage, click on the ‚ÄòSystems & Provisioning‚Äô dashboard at the right sidebar.  
  3. Navigate to the ‚ÄòAvailability‚Äô tab or locate the ‚ÄòAvailability Status‚Äô card from Overview tab. 
     

     


S-user ID Setup  

Ensure your S-User ID is assigned with one of the authorizations below:  

  • Display System Data.  
  • Edit System Data.  

Should you not have these permissions yet, please contact your company‚Äôs Super Administrator or use the Self-Service authorization request feature.

Finding your company‚Äôs Administrators
Locate your company‚Äôs Super, Cloud, or User Administrators via Users & Contacts‚ÄØ. Select ‚ÄòMy Important Contacts‚Äô tab or refer to the SAP Knowledge Base Article 3222501 for more details.   

Utilizing the Self-Service Authorization Request  
Request your authorizations by going to My Authorizations and Functions. Choose the ‚ÄòAuthorizations‚Äô tab and select ‚ÄòRequest Authorization‚Äô button.  
Detailed information and screenshots can be found on document 2891528 or on SAP Blog post How to use the Self-service authorisation request.  

Exploring the SAP Cloud Availability 

Accessing SAP Cloud Availability offers you a comprehensive view of your SAP Cloud services and systems, covering both productive and non-productive environments. Key insights include: 

  • Overview of supported cloud products (Check the list of all supported products on this webpage).  
  • Current and historical cloud system status. 
  • Planned events. 
  • Latest notifications. 
  • Communicated Availability Reporting. 

When reaching the application, the first card you will see is the Availability Status.  
 
It provides you with an overview of your cloud systems‚Äô status, quickly identifying unavailable systems or allowing you to filter for specific solutions. 
 

 

The three-dot icon on each card presents you with an explanation of the content; required authorizations; and data export option.  
 

 

 
 
Scrolling down the page, you‚Äôll find the Events card. This view enables you to check all events affecting your cloud systems in the last 12 months. It includes planned and unplanned activities such as maintenances, major upgrades, and service disruptions, allowing you to monitor the event status, impacted data centers, and other details.  
 
The card counts with filtering options as well as expand/collapse functionality based on your preferences.  

The Availability Reporting card displays communicated availability of your cloud services and systems over the past year.    


 
All of these details can be easily monitored and managed directly within SAP for Me. However, what if you want to receive email notification about system status updates, such as system outages, planned upgrades, or service disruptions? All you need is to subscribe yourself to the SAP Cloud Notifications.  
 
Check the SAP Knowledge Base Articles 2900069 and 2896942 for reference on how to subscribe for these notifications.
 
More information about SAP Cloud Availability can be found on the following resources:  

  • Cloud Availability in SAP for Me 
  • 2548400 - Getting started with the SAP Cloud Availability - SAP for Me 
     

Who to contact for support?  

In case of issues related to SAP Cloud Availability application, please create a case with SAP for Me technical team using the Get Support feature. Make sure that you select ‚ÄòSAP for Me‚Äô and ‚ÄòSystems & Provisioning > Availability‚Äô under product related fields to reach the correct team.  
 

More details can be checked in 1296527 - How to create a support case for SAP Support - SAP for Me.  

Alternatively, feel free to connect with the SAP Customer Interaction Center team for initial troubleshooting or navigation guidance. Our team is‚ÄØavailable 24/7‚ÄØensuring you are covered with a ‚Äúfollow the sun‚Äù support and service provided in‚ÄØover 10 languages.  
‚ÄØ 
Find the Customer Interaction Center official page and contact information on the following link:‚ÄØ Contact Customer Interaction Center‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
 
 

Thank you for reading! We hope you found this helpful and would love to hear your thoughts about this blog post. Let us know what you think!‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
‚ÄØ 
Stay tuned for our upcoming Support Webinars and recorded sessions to continuously learn and get the best from SAP Support:‚ÄØRegister Now‚ÄØ 

 

Read more #CustomerInteractionCenter‚ÄØblog posts‚ÄØhere!

entry.title: Re: How is DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN calculated in IO?
entry.content:
Hi @ahmed_zeeshan73 

The key figure DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is indeed one of the more opaque standard key figures in SAP IBP, as it is not fully explained in the help portal. Let me break it down:

Here is what it represents

  • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN equals average propagated demand that a receiving location places on its supplying locations.
  • It is used as an input into the demand variability propagation logic and therefore affecting PROPAGATEDDEMANDSTDEV and ultimately Recommended Safety Stock.

Here is how it is calculated

  1. Source Definition
    • The base definition comes from SAP‚Äôs Supply Planning sample content:
    • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN =   IFNULL(LOCDEMANDADJ, 0) + IFNULL(SHIPPEDQTY, 0) + IFNULL(CUSTOMERORDERSFINALADJ, 0)

depending on which demand inputs are active in your planning area.

  1. Calculation logic
    • At location product level, IBP calculates the mean demand per period at the receiving location.
    • This mean is then propagated upstream along the supply source relationship from customer ‚Üí DC ‚Üí plant.
    • If there are multiple supplying sources, the demand is split according to the Source of Supply share or heuristic allocation rules.
  2. Difference vs. SAP Note 2718582
    • SAP Note 2718582 describes how dependent demand is generally derived from receiving to supplying location.
    • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is not simply a direct copy of those equations, it is a statistical aggregation:
      • It takes actual or forecast consumption at the child node,
      • Adjusts for allocations,
      • And averages the demand over the defined horizon.
  3. Role in Safety Stock
    • This key figure‚Äôs standard deviation is used in PROPAGATEDDEMANDSTDEV.
    • Together with lead times and service levels, it influences Recommended Safety Stock in upstream nodes.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Inventory Optimization

What's New in SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain

entry.title: Re: Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit = Empty or Zero
entry.content:
Hi @louis_oli4 

I made a simple test within Learning Administration: went to a class > enabled the toggle 'Automatically add to learning history as part of VLS Attendance Processing' > set the For credit and Not-for-Credit Completion Statuses and left the filed 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' empty.

When trying to save, a pop-up is displayed: "The Minimum Attendance Percentage for Credit value is required. Enter a value that is greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100."

The same error is displayed when setting 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' with the value 0 and trying to save it.

In summary, this means the field 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' cannot be left empty and it only accepts values higher than 0 (zero).

I think the error is in the "Perpetual Cost Method" of the material master. If you set the Perpetual Cost Method as Standard in the material master, the difference between the purchase price and cost will be allocated to "differences" GL account. If you set the Perpetual Cost Method as the moving average, the purchase price is allocated against inventory account. 

 

regards,

entry.title: Re: Using data-gigya-api-link in screensets to call APIs...
entry.content:
Hi @damianomilani ,

API methods such as socialize.addConnection must be invoked through the SAP CDC JavaScript SDK, with all required parameters passed in JavaScript object. Passing parameters via HTML attributes is not supported and the SDK approach is the only officially supported method.

Also the data-gigya-api-link attribute is great for simple and declarative triggers like sending an OTP like your example or log out functionality. But for anything that requires dynamic input like choosing a social provider, passing user data then the SDK is the reliable and documented path.

Hope this is helpful

Regards,
Anand Raj

entry.title: Re: Changing materials without losing history
entry.content:
Hi @VickiG1 

Thank you for your question.

Your recycling scenario is a classic case where the chosen approach has to balance traceability such as batch genealogy and CoA with operational effort. Let me outline the main options and their implications in S/4HANA Public Cloud

First let us look at the challenge

  • Material-to-Material transfer posting. Requires Simple, low effort, it breaks traceability which means inspection results not carried forward and CoA cannot be generated with the original inspection results.
  • Secondary Process Order maintains production genealogy, new inspection lot can be created and results from the previous lot can be copied if required, provides full traceability for audit/CoA. Downside is, it requires more effort for Quality team to manage inspection lots

 

Below are the recommended Best Practice in Public Cloud

  1. Use a dedicated Grading Process Order type
    • After disassembly which is the first process order creates SFG, trigger a second process order for grading into the Finished Goods which is then the graded materials.
    • Doing it that way means, you:
      • Maintain batch classification and genealogy from original widget ‚Üí SFG ‚Üí FG.
      • Have a new inspection lot tied to the FG material.
      • Can configure result recording copy rules to bring forward relevant results from the SFG inspection lot into the FG inspection lot.
  2. Leverage Batch Derivation or Batch Classification
    • Activate batch derivation so that the graded FG inherits batch characteristics.
    • This ensures traceability back to the original widget batches without manual effort.
  3. Inspection Lot Handling
    • Use Usage Decision with Copy Results. The inspection lot for the FG can inherit results from the SFG lot.
    • In Public Cloud, the app Manage Usage Decisions and Record Inspection Results can be configured to pull forward results automatically.

 

What you should refrain from

  • Pure material-to-material transfer posting ‚Üí You will lose genealogy and inspection traceability. This may look simple but it will not meet audit/CoA requirements in regulated or customer-facing industries.

 

Batch Management in S/4HANA Cloud

Quality Management in Production

Disassembly in Process Manufacturing (Scope Item 1F0)

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to understand which usage objects will be collect...
entry.content:
As outlined in KBA 3207350 - CCLM How-to-Guides, on page 17, chapter Collecting Usage:

  • "Usage can only be collected during runtime. This means, that CCLM can only record usage for runtime objects. These runtime objects do not match in all cases with the design-time objects. CCLM collects objects from TADIR which are design-time objects".

For more information, see also:

  • https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/pdf/preview/embed/BQWpoPm?ltr=a
  • KBA 2431632 - Object Types Whose Usage Information Can Be Analyzed in Custom Code Lifecycle Management (CCLM)

entry.title: Building Empathy into Design
entry.content:
(authored by Nicole Windmann, VP, Head of Accessible Software Development)

In today's world, where digital technology is ever-present, designing accessible software isn't just a requirement‚Äîit's a responsibility. At SAP, accessibility is not merely about checking off a list of requirements or meeting technical guidelines like those outlined in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG). It's about creating intuitive, inclusive experiences that work for everyone, regardless of ability. By embedding accessibility early in the software development lifecycle and prioritizing user-centric design, SAP continues to lead with empathy and innovation.

A man using ASL signs "Thank you" to an unseen person on his computer screen. Text reads "1.3 billion people worldwide have a disability. 9 in 10 people with a disability acquire it through illness, injury or aging. SAP designs for all users. Stay tuned to learn more about how SAP strives for more inclusive experiences."

From Compliance to Compassion: Why Accessibility Needs a Human Lens
WCAG serve as the foundation for creating accessibility experiences. They ensure that software is technically usable by people with disabilities, but they don't always guarantee that these experiences feel intuitive, seamless, or empowering. That's where a user-centered approach makes all the difference.

Designing with empathy means listening to people who, for example, rely on assistive technologies. It means understanding that a screen reader user's experience with your app may differ greatly from that of a mouse user, and that merely focusing on color contrast doesn't account for cognitive load or task complexity, among other considerations.

At SAP, we believe accessibility should not be an afterthought. It should be integrated from the very first sketch of a user interface, and carried through research, design, development, and testing. That's why we advocate for a "shift left" in accessibility, embedding inclusive practices early in the design and development lifecycle to catch issues before they become barriers.

Introducing the Accessibility Design Tools: Empathy Meets Innovation
One of the standout achievements in SAP's accessibility journey was the publication of the Accessibility Design Tools ‚Äî a new suite of resources designed to operationalize accessibility in the design process. The supporting handbook didn't just explain how to meet accessibility standards, it showcased why it matters.

From identifying potential friction points early to validating design decisions with real users, the Accessibility Design Tools, together with the Inclusive Research Handbook, are built to encourage empathy-driven decisions. They have since become a reference point for inclusive design in our enterprise software, bridging the gap between compliance and empathy.

Some Standout Features Include:

  • Accessibility Annotation Library for designs
  • Plug-ins for keyboard and screen-reading order
  • A handbook to educate on accessibility and guide through the usage of the annotations

The success of the tools demonstrated that when accessibility is framed as a shared responsibility‚Äîwith resources, support, and clear guidance‚Äîinnovation flourishes. It also proved that inclusive design doesn't slow teams down; it makes products stronger, more resilient, and more user-friendly for all. Whether you're a designer, developer, product manager, or advocate, you'll find practical tools, inspiring stories, and a growing community committed to building a more accessible world.

Inclusive Design is a Mindset‚ÄîNot a Milestone
Accessibility is a continuous journey that requires awareness, empathy, and cross-functional collaboration. It also requires a shift in thinking: from designing for users with disabilities to creating with them.

At SAP, we're committed to keeping accessibility at the heart of our design culture. That means:

  • Prioritizing early involvement of accessibility experts in projects
  • Investing in tools for designers and developers
  • Listening to real users and valuing their lived experiences
  • Advocating for inclusive design as a core value, not an add-on

And most importantly, it means recognizing that accessibility is everyone's responsibility, not solely the job of specialists or compliance officers.

Call to Action: Stay Connected, Stay Inclusive
Since SAP first published Accessibility Design Tools, we have learned a great deal and welcomed lots of feedback. Internal and external design communities provided insight and inspiration. This feedback encouraged us to review our Accessibility Design Tools from a user-centric perspective, and we are excited that the updated Accessibility Design Tools will be available soon!

Let's think beyond compliance. Let's design with empathy. And let's make sure no one is left behind.

entry.title: Re: Required Configuration Activityies between Developmen...
entry.content:
Hi Marton,

For each one of the Tenants (Development or Customizing) you can proceed with the Scoping, Organizational Setup, and Configuration (Product-Specific Configuration) separately on each Workspace created in SAP Central Business Configuration.

The Development System is where the business processes are activated, configured, and customized. These changes made in the development system are transported to the test system and further, to the Production system.

When you perform the Product-Specific Configuration in the Dev Customizing tenant (Client 100), the same configuration will not become available in the Dev Development tenant (Client 080) given that the Customizing Tenant is Client-Dependent.

In the Development System we have these 2 Main tenants (Customizing and Development) and the additional Tenant (D.120) for Parallel Line:

Development Tenant: The development tenant provides access to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud ABAP Environment. In this environment, you can build your own custom developments based on lifecycle-stable SAP objects. The development tenant is client-independent, meaning development objects built here can be accessed from the customizing tenant if permission is granted in a matter of Development. 

This is the tenant where development and extensibility activities take place and where configurations can be validated before being moved to the test tenant.

For more information about the available extensibility options, see:

  • Extensibility
  • Developer Extensibility.

Customizing Tenant: Customizing tenant / client 100 is the main workspace, used for business process configuration and key user extensibility with the SAP Fiori extensibility apps. The customizing tenant is client-dependent, meaning configurations or extensions made here can only be accessed within the customizing tenant. This is because master and transactional data is stored in database tables within a client column. Changes to business configuration in this tenant are recorded on customizing requests and are released for transport with the Export Customizing Requests Fiori app. Key user extensions built with the SAP Fiori extensibility apps in this tenant are added to software collections and released for transport with the Export Software Collections Fiori app.
This is the tenant where business configuration or system adjustments are made without development activities. Used to set up the solution according to the business needs before it is transported to test and production.

  • Configuration activities based on the reference content from SAP Central Business Configuration. For more information, see Configuration with SAP Central Business Configuration (3-System Landscape).

  • To make your configuration content available in the test and production systems, you need to transport them. For more information about transports in the 3-system landscape, see Configuration Environment in a 3-System Landscape.

  • Create low-code custom developments in key user apps. For more information, see Key User Extensibility.

Parallel Customizing Tenant: The parallel customizing tenant is part of the parallel line, which allows you to create and test configuration enhancements without affecting your main line or production system. In the parallel customizing tenant, you actively work on your parallel line content before forwarding it to the parallel test tenant for testing. For more information, see Parallel Line in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

I hope this clarifies your questions.

Please see these related and additional information:

  • System Landscapes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Configure Your Business Processes | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Key User Extensibility | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Configuration Environment in a 3-System Landscape | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Tenants in the Development System | SAP Help Portal

  • 3-System Landscape and Transport Management | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards,

Marcelo

SAP Support

entry.title: Ensuring DSCSA Compliance Readiness: How SAP Supports the Life Sciences Supply Chain
entry.content:
SAP Serialization Track & Trace Solutions for Life Sciences

 

As the pharmaceutical industry moves through the final stages of DSCSA (Drug Supply Chain Security Act) implementation, 2025 marks the decisive year. After the successful onboarding of manufacturers in May, the spotlight is now on wholesalers as they approach their August 27, 2025 enforcement deadline. The final phase will then bring dispensers (>25 FTE) into full compliance by November 27, 2025, closing the loop on DSCSA‚Äôs 10-year rollout.

With strict mandates around unit-level traceability, electronic data exchange, and real-time product verification, pharmaceutical stakeholders are increasingly turning to SAP‚Äôs serialization and traceability ecosystem to ensure compliance with confidence.

SAP's serialization solutions are used by 18 of the top 20 global pharmaceutical manufacturers, 2 of the Big 3 U.S. wholesalers, and major dispensers to enable real-time data exchange and compliance at scale. Source: Fierce Pharma 2024 revenue

Key Areas of Focus:

üìÖDSCSA Compliance Timelines and Stakeholder responsibility - 

‚úÖMay 27, 2025 ‚Äì Manufacturers Hit Milestone

By May 27, 2025, pharmaceutical manufacturers successfully achieved:

  • Transactional Information data exchange with downstream partners
  • Full serialization and aggregation workflows
  • Real-time product verification through Verification Router Service (VRS)
  • Integration for traceability and regulatory reporting
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

This demonstrated success of the 18 largest global manufacturers adoption SAP serialization has created a strong foundation that downstream partners can build upon in their journey toward DSCSA compliance. This milestone offers both a technical model and regulatory guide, enabling partners to ensure interoperability, product traceability, and compliance with FDA requirements.

üìÖAugust 27, 2025 ‚Äì Wholesalers Enforcement Begins

As of August 27, 2025, wholesalers must be fully compliant with all DSCSA requirements:

  • Interoperable EPCIS 1.2 data exchange with both suppliers and customers
  • Verification of serialized product identifiers, especially for saleable returns
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

This deadline marks the end of the FDA‚Äôs one-year stabilization period and phased exemption period, formalizing wholesalers obligation to support serialized traceability across the U.S. supply chain.

üïíNovember 27, 2025 ‚Äì Dispensers Join the Compliance Chain

The final phase of DSCSA goes live on November 27, 2025, when dispensers (pharmacies, hospitals, clinics) must also begin:

  • Receiving and storing serialized EPCIS data
  • Verifying product identifiers on suspect or returned products
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

While dispensers were given more time to prepare, their participation is essential to close the loop on product traceability and patient safety.

Latest updates from FDA can be found here. 

 üíº How SAP Supports DSCSA Compliance End-to-End

SAP provides a full suite of serialization and traceability tools tailored for life sciences‚Äîhelping manufacturers, wholesalers, and dispensers comply at every stage.

üè∑Ô∏è   SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (SAP ATTP)

A proven solution for managing serialization across packaging lines, SAP ATTP enables:

  • Serial number generation, aggregation, and disaggregation
  • Integration with ERP systems
  • Global compliance with DSCSA, including EU FMD, and others
  • Regulatory reporting and audit traceability
  • Product history and exception management
üîó SAP Information Collaboration Hub for Life Sciences (SAP ICH)

SAP ICH powers secure, real-time data exchange between trading partners:

  • EPCIS data exchange across the supply chain
  • Verification Router Service (VRS) integration
  • Trace request and response workflows
  • Exception Management
  • Secure sharing of serialized data with trading partners
  • Ongoing support for FDA and industry interoperability guidelines

SAP ICH is essential for wholesalers and dispensers to receive, verify, and manage serialized data at scale.

‚úÖ SAP: A Trusted Partner in DSCSA Compliance

SAP‚Äôs serialization ecosystem is trusted by leading organizations worldwide.
It is used by 18 of the top 20 global pharmaceutical manufacturers, 2 of the Big 3 U.S. wholesalers, and major dispensers to enable real-time data exchange and compliance at scale. The platform supports one of the largest networks in Life Sciences, connecting over 6,000 entities and processing an average of 1.5 million messages per month.

SAP provides:

  • üåçGlobal regulatory alignment
  • üîÑEnd-to-end serialization and verification
  • üß© Secure, interoperable data exchange
  • üõ°Proven infrastructure and audit readiness
  • üìàProven architecture for large volumes and scalability
  • üöÄRapid partner onboarding through proprietary self-onboarding tools
  • üîêRobust infrastructure to handle regulatory audits and trace requests
  • ‚ÅâÔ∏èUtilities for swift management of exception 
  • üìâReduced manual efforts with automated exception handling
  • üåçGlobal scalability for multi-market traceability (beyond DSCSA)

üîö Final Thoughts

The May 27 success for manufacturers proved that industry-wide compliance is achievable. Now, with August 27 and November 27 on the horizon, the entire U.S. pharma supply chain must move in sync to fulfill the promise of the Drug Supply Chain Security Act: protecting patients through transparency, trust, and traceability.

With SAP ATTP and SAP ICH, every step of the DSCSA journey is covered from serialization to final dispense.

SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (SAP ATTP)

SAP Information Collaboration Hub for Life Sciences (SAP ICH)

Hear directly from our customers : Bristol-Myers Squibb , Boehringer Ingelheim

Hi SAP Community,


There are many apps to display actual costs, depending on the information you would like to retrieve. You can use app Material Inventory Values - Balance Summary / CDS View I_ML_BALANCE to check actual costs for material.

For price/activity information, check CDS View I_InventoryPriceByKeyDate and Activity Consumption Analysis for consumption of Cost Center.

There is also app Manage Material Valuations to display an overview of valuation data for your materials.

Kindly refer to the below documentation:

  • 3097384 - App/CDS Views to check actual costs - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Feature Comparison for Material Valuations and Price Changes
  • CDS Views for Management Accounting and Margin Analysis


Best Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: üí°BTP Trial Platform SSO ‚Äì Game Changer for New Customers & POCs
entry.content:
üöÄüîê‚ú®Enabling Platform SSO for SAP BTP Trial Accounts using SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS)

About Me

Hare Krishna üôè I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

üåüIntroduction

Until recently, SAP BTP Trial accounts did not support Platform SSO. This meant that trial users had to rely on S-User IDs or SAP IDs for cockpit access, making it harder to onboard new users quickly for POCs (Proof of Concepts).

With the latest update, Platform SSO is now available for Trial accounts as well! üéâ

This is a huge enabler for:

  • New customers exploring SAP BTP for the first time.

  • Partners and developers who want to quickly set up POCs.

  • Teams that want to onboard users without waiting for an S-User.

  • Anyone looking to integrate IAS (Identity Authentication Service) or external IdPs like Azure AD, Okta, etc. for authentication.

üëâIn short: You can now enable SSO in your Trial just like in Enterprise accounts, which makes POCs faster, more secure, and realistic while giving new customers a smooth onboarding experience.

üåüAdvantages at a Glance

  • Seamless SSO: Log in to BTP cockpit and CLI with one identity.

  • Flexible IdP Options: Use IAS or integrate with Azure AD, Okta, or other IdPs.

  • Faster POCs & Onboarding: New trial users can get started without an SAP S-user.

  • Enhanced Security: Centralized user management, MFA, and consistent policies via IAS.

  • Scalable Setup: The same trust model works when you move from trial to productive accounts.

üìäFlow Diagram (Text-Based)

[User Login] 
     ‚îÇ
     ‚ñº
[BTP Cockpit / CLI] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ> [Redirect to IAS] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ> [Authenticate with IAS User]
     ‚îÇ
     ‚ñº
[Return to BTP Global/Subaccount] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ> [Access Cockpit / CLI with IAS Identity]
‚Äã

üîëWhy Platform SSO is a Game-Changer

  1. Unified Login Experience
    Platform SSO centralizes access for all BTP platform users. Whether you use IAS or a corporate IdP (Azure AD, Okta, Ping, etc.), everyone authenticates the same way ‚Äî no juggling multiple accounts.

  2. Security & Compliance
    With IAS or enterprise IdPs, you can enforce strong security controls: MFA, conditional access, SCIM provisioning, and user lifecycle policies. This significantly improves compliance posture compared to standalone trial logins.

  3. Faster POCs & Onboarding
    Before, trial accounts required S-Users which slowed down enablement. Now customers, partners, and developers can get started instantly with IAS-based trial logins. That means faster POCs, demos, and hackathon setups.

  4. Developer Productivity
    Developers can seamlessly use the same IAS login in both BTP Cockpit and BTP CLI. This avoids login confusion and makes CLI automation scripts more consistent.

  5. Future-Proof Architecture
    Platform SSO with IAS scales from trial to production. What you set up for trial POCs can be extended to full enterprise setups without redesigning your security model.

üîºHigh-Level Steps

  1. Enable & Activate Cloud Identity Services (IAS)
    Subscribe to IAS from your BTP global account. You‚Äôll get an activation email to set up your tenant.

  2. Establish Trust Between BTP and IAS
    Configure trust in BTP cockpit so that IAS acts as the identity provider.

  3. Create Users
    Create a user in IAS, then create the same user in BTP cockpit against IAS IdP and assign required roles.

  4. Login via Platform SSO URL
    Access BTP cockpit using the Platform SSO URL that redirects to IAS for authentication.

  5. Verify Access in Trial Account
    Ensure the IAS user lands successfully in the trial subaccount.

  6. Extend SSO to BTP CLI
    Log in to BTP CLI using the same IAS credentials.

‚öôÔ∏èStep-by-Step Guide

Step 1: Create IAS Tenant (Cloud Identity Services)

  • Subscribe to SAP Cloud Identity Services (default subscription).

  • You‚Äôll receive an activation email to set up your IAS tenant.

  • This IAS tenant will serve as the trusted IdP for BTP platform login.

üîóExample IAS Tenant:
aym6uhvub.trial-accounts.ondemand.com

Step 2: Configure Trust at Global Account Level

  1. Navigate to your Global Account in BTP Cockpit.

  2. Go to: Security ‚Üí Trust Configuration ‚Üí Establish Trust.

  3. Select your IAS tenant.

  4. Configure:

    • Tenant

    • Domain

    • Origin Key (unique identifier)

  5. Review & confirm.

‚úÖOnce done, IAS will appear as a Custom Identity Provider for Platform Users.

üîëStep 3: Create & Assign Users

  • First, create the user in IAS (example: btptrialiasuser@test.com).

  • Then, go to BTP cockpit ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Users, and create the same user against the IAS IdP you configured.

  • Finally, assign the appropriate roles/role collections (e.g., Global Account Admin, Subaccount Admin, or custom role collections).

Create user in IAS

Create user in BTP Global account

Assign User required privileges

Step 4: Login URL Creation

Use the following syntax to generate IAS login URL for cockpit access:

https://<TENANTID>.<REGION>.hana.ondemand.com/cockpit?idp=<TRUSTEDIDP>.accounts.ondemand.com
 
üîóExample (trial):
https://account.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial?idp=aym6uhvub.trial-accounts.ondemand.com#/home/trial

üëâHere, aym6uhvub is the IAS tenant identifier (highlighted).

Step 5: Authenticate with IAS

  • Open the URL ‚Üí You‚Äôll be redirected to IAS login screen.

  • Enter IAS user credentials (e.g., btptrialiasuser@test.com).

  • On successful login ‚Üí Click ‚ÄúGo to Your Trial Account‚Äù.

‚ú®You‚Äôre now inside the BTP Cockpit with IAS credentials (instead of S-User).

üîêLogging in with IAS via BTP CLI

Apart from cockpit login, SAP BTP CLI also supports Platform SSO with IAS.
This is especially useful for developers and administrators working with scripts, automation, or CI/CD pipelines.

Steps to Login

  1. Open your terminal.

  2. Run the following command with your IAS details and origin key:

 
btp login --idp <ORIGIN_KEY> --user <yourIASuser@example.com> --password <yourPassword>

Verify the Login

After successful login, you can test by listing your subaccounts:

btp list accounts/subaccount

 

‚úÖThis confirms that IAS-based authentication works not only in the cockpit but also with BTP CLI, making Platform SSO truly end-to-end.

‚ùìFAQs ‚Äì Platform SSO for BTP Trial

Q1: Can I use Platform SSO in a Trial account without an S-User?
A: Yes! Trial accounts now support Platform SSO via IAS or any configured Identity Provider. You no longer need an S-User for cockpit or CLI access.

Q2: Do I need to create a user in both IAS and BTP?
A: Yes. Create the user in IAS first, then create the corresponding user in BTP linked to the IAS IdP and assign the necessary roles.

Q3: Can I use Azure AD or another IdP instead of IAS?
A: Yes, any trusted Identity Provider configured at the global account level can be used for Platform SSO.

Q4: Does Platform SSO work for both cockpit and CLI?
A: Absolutely. You can log in to BTP cockpit via the SSO URL and to BTP CLI using the --idp and origin key.

Q5: Why is an origin key needed for CLI login?
A: The origin key tells the CLI which Identity Provider to use for authentication, especially when multiple IdPs are configured.

Q6: Is Platform SSO secure?
A: Yes. By using IAS or any trusted IdP, authentication is centralized, supports MFA, and follows enterprise-grade security policies.

üéØConclusion

With Platform SSO now enabled for trial accounts, SAP has made it much easier for new customers, partners, and developers to:

  • Run POCs faster üöÄ

  • Onboard trial users without S-User IDs üîë

  • Experience enterprise-grade SSO with IAS üîí

This change is a big step forward for customer adoption and onboarding in SAP BTP.

üôè Thank You

A special thanks to SAP for enabling Platform SSO in Trial accounts, making it easier for new customers, partners, and developers to explore SAP BTP securely and efficiently.
This update truly accelerates POCs, onboarding, and hands-on learning for everyone.
